required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Correction of Farsightedness in Children Study
clinical_study.official_title: Correction of Hyperopia in Children Study

collaborator.agency: College of Optometrists in Vision Development

brief_summary.textblock: The Correction of Hyperopia In Children Study (CHICS) is a placebo-controlled, randomized, masked investigation of the effect of spectacle correction for moderate amounts of hyperopia on visual function, attention, and reading skills in children.

detailed_description.textblock: Hyperopia (farsightedness) has been reported to be associated with reduced visual perceptual and reading abilities. However, there is controversy regarding whether or not to prescribe for low to moderate amounts of hyperopia. The Correction of Hyperopia In Children Study (CHICS) is a placebo-controlled, randomized, masked investigation of the effect of spectacle correction for moderate amounts of hyperopia on visual function, attention, and reading skills in children.

study_design_info.masking: Quadruple (Participant, Care Provider, Investigator, Outcomes Assessor)

primary_outcome.measure: Change in Kaufman Test of Educational Achievement (K-TEA) reading comprehension score as measured after 6 weeks of assigned treatment (hyperopic or control correction)
primary_outcome.description: Individually administered battery that provides in-depth assessment of key academic skills

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in Cognitive Assessment System (CAS) Attention scores as measured after 6 weeks of assigned treatment (hyperopic or control correction)
secondary_outcome.description: Individually administered battery designed to measure cognitive processing abilities. CAS is based on PASS (Planning, Attention, Simultaneous, and Successive), a well-researched cognitive/neuropsychological theory.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in accommodative response after 6 weeks of assigned treatment (hyperopic or control correction)
secondary_outcome.description: Accommodative response by monocular estimation method (MEM)

facility.name: Illinois College of Optometry/Illinois Eye Institute
SUNY College of Optometry/University Optometric Center
